fdd:description.p: An XML-based format, developed by the International Press Telecommunications Council. NITF represents the content and structure of news articles and accompanying metadata. The intent of NITF is as a base format, from which publishers can adapt the look, feel, and interactivity of their documents to the bandwidth, devices, and personalized needs of their subscribers. NITF documents can be translated into HTML, WML (for wireless devices), RTF (for printing), or any other format the publisher wishes.
This format description does not attempt to distinguish between versions, but covers NITF in general.

fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:productionPhase: A middle-state format (intended for use by publishers and newswire services).

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: Originally, only a DTD was used.
As of version 3.4, released in May 2007, an XML Schema for NITF has been made available.

fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: See the Recommended Formats Statement for the Library of Congress format preferences for Textual Works.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Open standard. NITF was developed by the International Press Telecommunications Council, an independent international association of news agencies and publishers.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:documentation: NITF specifications can be found at https://iptc.org/standards/nitf/
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:adoption: Substantial adoption by newswire services. See https://iptc.org/standards/nitf/whos-using-nitf/.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation: The DTD includes descriptive elements relevant to news articles, such as title, byline, dateline, headline. Also in the DTD are elements for topical subjects, publication details, and revision history.

fdd:textQF.fdd:structure: The NITF DTDs and XML Schemas represent the structure of an individual news article.
fdd:textQF.fdd:layout: Not intended to define precise rendering, but to support rendering using stylesheets for different disseminations, via PDAs, RSS, web browsers, etc. Â Includes HTML-compatible support for tables and lists.
fdd:textQF.fdd:beyondText: Supports links to external media objects, such as images, audio, or video. Also supports embedding of media objects (in binary format).

fdd:filenameExtension.fdd:note: Common practice for XML document instances is to use the .xml extension. The particular XML Schema or DTD should be declared within the document.

fdd:history.p: Version 3.2 of NITF was released in October 2003. Version 3.4 was released in May 2007. Version 3.5 was released in September 2009. Version 3.6 was released in January 2012. For version 3.6, only an XML Schema is specified.
